title: Photographing the  Bundu Helmet Masks of the Mende Peoples in Sierra Leone
title_display: Lecture: Photographing the Bundu Helmet Masks of the Mende Peoples in Sierra Leone
hero_caption: Helmet Mask (Sherbro or Mende), Early-mid 20th century. Sierra Leone. Wood. Through prior acquisitions of the George F. Harding Collection, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Molner, and the Ada Turnbull Hertle Endowment.
short_description: Julie Crooks, Head of Global Arts of Africa and the Diaspora at the Art Gallery of Ontario (Toronto), discusses the career of Alphonso Lisk-Carew (1883-1969), one of the few local, Sierra Leonean professional photographers of the early 20th century.
list_description: Julie Crooks, Head of Global Arts of Africa and the Diaspora at the Art Gallery of Ontario (Toronto), discusses the career of Alphonso Lisk-Carew (1883-1969), one of the few local, Sierra Leonean professional photographers of the early 20th century.
description:
The famous helmet masks used in Sierra Leone and neighboring Liberia and Guinea have been documented by several foreign photographers since the late 19th century, starting with the 1901 monograph by the British colonial administrator T.J. Alldridge. Such historical photographs are often included in African art exhibitions to help contextualize the objects on display. Julie Crooks, head of Global Arts of Africa and the Diaspora at the Art Gallery of Ontario (Toronto), discusses the compelling career of Alphonso Lisk-Carew (1883–1969), one of the few local Sierra Leonean professional photographers of the early 20th century.

This program complements the exhibition The Language of Beauty in African Art, which brings together more than 250 sculptures and other art forms from dozens of distinct cultures across the African continent.

About the Speaker

This lecture is made possible by the Frank J. Mooney Memorial Fund.

Please note that this is an in-person event that takes place at the museum.
